newsitem.title: INDIA: PRESS DIGEST - Indian newspapers - September 24.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Indian newspapers - September 24.

text.p: Following is a summary of major Indian business and political stories in leading newspapers prepared for REUTERS by Business News and Information Services Pvt Ltd, New Delhi Tel:3326806, 3326813, 3326849 Fax:+91-11-3351006 E-mail: biznis@giasbm01.vsnl.net.in
The Times Of India
CONGRESS TREASURER BECOMES PARTY'S INTERIM PRESIDENT

Congress treasurer Sitaram Kesri was elected the party's interim president at the Congress Working Committee (CWC) meeting. Sources said former Prime Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao placed his resignation before the CWC at the beginning of the meeting, requesting the members not to force him to withdraw it.

Barring Rajesh Pilot, Kesri's name was by and large acceptable to all CWC members. Sources said Pilot suggested that the senior most party general secretary should discharge the duties of acting president till the election of a new president by the All India Congress Committee.
The Hindustan Times
BHARATIYA JANATA PARTY CHIEF'S TRIAL STAYED TILL OCTOBER 30

The Delhi High Court has stayed till October 30 the trial of Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) president L.K. Advani in the Hawala (illegal foreign exchange) case. Advani has been charged by the Central Bureau of Investigation of having received six million rupees as illegal gratification from the Jain brothers, principal accused in the case. The court's order is being seen as a major reprieve for the BJP on the eve of the crucial Uttar Pradesh Assembly elections.
Financial Express
MNCS JOIN THE RACE TO REVIVE SICK STATE UNIT

Some half a dozen foreign bidders have put in bids to support the 43.48 billion rupee revival package for the Indian Iron and Steel Company Ltd (Iisco). These include global giants like Mitsubishi and Mitsui. This is the first time that a multinational company has come forward to take over a sick public sector company with minority participation. The stake being offered to private participants in the Iisco revival scheme is only 37 percent.
BHILWARA SPURNS HOECHST'S OVERTURES

The Jhunjhunwalas of the 12-billion rupee Bhilwara group spurned an offer by Hoechst of Germany to give the latter a substantial equity stake in their group company, HEG Ltd. Bhilwara group chairman L.N. Jhunjhunwala confirmed Hoechst was interested in taking over the graphite electrode manufacturing company. He, however, said his group was not interested in the offer. Hoechst had even offered to take over the company by buying out the entire stake of Jhunjhunwalas.
The Economic Times
LEFT FRONT'S RED SIGNAL TO EXPENDITURE PANEL

The move to set up an expenditure management and reforms commission has been put on hold primarily due to resistance from the Communist partners of the United Front (UF) government. Finance Minister P. Chidambaram had earlier announced that the commission would be asked to submit its report within four months. Sources said UF partners were reluctant to concretise the proposal because of the sensitive nature of the commission, which would look into the entire gamut of issues relating to the government spending, including administrative expenditure, subsidies and budgetary support to the public sector.
BANKS NEED NOT SHOW THEIR HANDS FOR ISSUES

Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI), the bourse regulator, has permitted banks and financial institutions (FIs) to go ahead with their public offerings without giving any future financial projections. Prospectuses of banks and FIs would henceforth contain only details of past performance. SEBI sources said manufacturing companies whose projects were financed by the appraising authority in a greenfield project could give projections. However, these would have to be ratified by the appraising FIs.
TELECOM DEPARTMENT'S BUG-RIDDEN TENDER SCRAPPED AFTER A YEAR

The Telecom Commission has decided to scrap a 1.6 billion rupee tender for purchase of SDH transmission equipment. The decision came one year after the opening of tender as the tender conditions did not clearly mention the technical specifications. This was the first time that a public sector company, the Indian Telecom Industries, was the lowest bidder in any tender floated by the Department of Telecommunications ever since the gates were opened to the private sector.
